comments.commentBody: Producers saved $12 million..this cast would not have worked..no one can  touch Streisand in the part & it would have come off like a high school pretend production..Many of these shows can get decent productions in   concert venues at Lincoln Center & eventually move to Broadway as slimmed down versions of themselves, but still can be vastly entertaining with less book and more music/dance  (i.e. Chicago) & run for many years..
Disappointing! Lauren Ambrose is fabulous!
Gary Coleman would have been perfect, alas!

Quite frankly, though I find Lauren Ambrose to be a very talented actress, it is difficult for me to see a short, chubby non-jewish redhead, who lacks the range for the music of this play, as the lead.

Someone of the ilk of say, Farrah Alvin, would have been a much better choice, considering her incredible voiceand expressive eyes and face, not to mention comedic timing. I have been a big fan since seeing her in Pirates of Penzance, and the fabulous "Marvelous Wonderettes", where she belted out tune after tube. my friends and I, all products of the '60's, saw it over and over again whenever we had out-of-town guests. I bought the cd and don't tire of playing in on my car radio, singing along to all the wonderful music.
Look her up on youtube and see for yourself.
I don't think it was just about money. Funny Girl is a musical that just can't be revived on Broadway - it is Streisand - and without her it is nothing.

Audra McDonald as Fanny Brice would have been an inspired choice, and would perhaps have made the economic difference as well.  She has always, and I mean always, wanted to play the role, and think of the controversial publicity.  She has the voice and acting ability as well.

Sheep, like cattle and other ruminants, are a significant global source of methane, the second most important greenhouse gas. I'm not convinced that creating another reason to increase the population of sheep is a benefit for the environment. Just because something seems "natural" doesn't make it good for nature. A human-powered reel mower is a much greener way to keep the grass trimmed.

One of the issues discussed in the briefing is that economic espionage using hacking and other computer technology is being contracted by both government agencies and business organizations to private parties. This provides a degree of deniability for the governments and a freedom to operate to the private parties.

In a sense, rather than conducting open warfare on the high seas with conventionally flagged navies, this is a war in which privateers are being issued letters of marque to attack merchant shipping. In such a war it is impossible to tell who is a privateer and who is an out-and-out pirate. Respectable nations simply have to treat privateers and pirates the same.

I commend to your attention the "Self Sufficiency Standard Studies" which come from a standardized methodology developed by Diana Pearce, at the University of Washington. To date, they've been conducted for perhaps 35 states over the past 15 or so years. They provide a localized -- county-level -- cost of living for various configurations of families with heads of working age. Offshoot studies in selected states provide (1) similar data for elderly people; and (2) counts of people whose incomes are below the SSS for their size/type of family in their particular county.

The most notable figure I've found in these studies -- among many others -- is one they don't directly calculate, but which one can calculate based on a simple assumption: the percentage of the children in the particular state who live in families whose income is insufficient to meet the most modestly defined needs (how is that for a euphemism?!).

For the 4 states for which I've done the calculation, I've found that 40% of all children live in such families. 40%.

Take that figure in, and then think about its implications, for those children, for the classrooms they're in, for their teachers, for their classmates, and for America's future.

Martin Luther King said that a society that is designed to create beggars needs restructuring. When 40% of our youngsters are growing up in families whose income is insufficient to meet basic needs, we're wrongly structured.

What are we to do about it? The best answers I know come from the ideas of Henry George (b. 1839, Philadelphia; d. NYC, 1897), the author of "Progress and Poverty" and "Social Problems" and of some wonderful speeches. Check out http://www.wealthandwant.com/ and http://lvtfan.typepad.com/ to introduce yourself to his ideas. I embraced them only after I couldn't find anything else. I invite you to be a faster learner than I was.

While certainly this country has more than its share of poor, it is about time that someone took a serious look at what it really means to be "below the poverty" level. Many have mistakenly looked at this recession as being near the calamity of the Great Depression. If you truly look at what people have, and the quality of life in this country, those who suffered through the Great Depression must certainly think we are a group of "whiners" for the amount of suffering we endure. For many of us, if we do not have three bathrooms, a triple garage, six TVS, a cell phone for each of the members of our family, an SUV, and two credit cards, we are below the poverty level.

I left a Bible study class at my church some years ago when the retired C.E.O, of a bankrupt cafeteria chain ranted against minimum wages and sustainable wages and the little liberal pastor ignored his outburst. He also attacked unions. What was remarkable was his outburst came while we were studying The Letter of James, chapter 5, which is about cheating employees.

After I retired, I took a part-time job with J. C. Penney. Those people were awful. They changed my hours constantly. They paid only slightly over minimum wage but that was not a problem for me. What was a problem was that they refused to work with me on establishing hours or the length of the work week. I would often work seven days in row but they discounted that by saying I worked four days one week and three the next week. The problem was that the progression of days was seven in a row. The kind of abuse of employees seems standard in retail sales now. Our union free society has destroyed our people and our lives.
I believe the point is that poverty rates have grown significantly---5 million is still a huge number in this wealthy nation. We have a problem Houston whatever agency is reporting the figures.

The idea that a family of four living on $18,800 per year isn't poor is not only insulting, it's obscene.  No American Dream for this family; they join the ranks living the American Nightmare. I defy anyone to buy a home, a car, auto, property and health insurance;feed, clothe, house, treat for illness and educate yourself and 3 children on $18,800 a year in today's ever-rising costs world.  Those who are lucky enough to have even that know all too well exactly what they are: the working poor.

Agree with Longview. Poverty is a relative thing, mostly; it rarely involves death or starvation although it certainly correlates quite well with disease and with limited opportunity. There is too much poverty, of both the absolute and the relative sort. In a rich country people should be guaranteed an adequate diet, housing, clothing, essential health care, and access to education and to other necessary infrastructure, and investments in future prosperity should continue to be made, by the whole society, for the whole society.

Nothing says everyone should enjoy equal freedoms and extravagances, far from it. But there is a decent argument to be made, that all benefit when none suffer and when all have opportunity.
